content.rendered:
What is a Database Administrator?

Database Administrators use specialized software to organize data specific to a company’s area of work.

Where does a Database Administrator work?

  • Computer systems services
  • Educational services
  • Management companies
  • Insurance companies

How much does a Database Administrator make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Database Administrator is $49,000.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Database Administrators?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Computer science majors
  • Software engineering majors
  • General engineering majors
Search Database Administrator jobs on Handshake

Database Administrator skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Database Administrators succeed in their work:

  • Attention to detail
  • Teamwork and collaboration
  • Knowledge of relevant computer languages

What are some common questions about Database Administrators?

Q: How do I become a Database Administrator?

A: Ideally, after you’ve gotten your bachelor’s degree in a relevant field, you can become a Database Administrator by learning key computer languages and accumulating experience–from internships, courses and jobs.

excerpt.rendered: Learn about the average salary, relevant studies, related questions, and common path after college to becoming Database Administrators.
